STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
(Amended)
January 4, 2023
Franchesca MARIA Vega
WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - SOUTHCENTRAL
1801 E CANFIELD ST,
DETROIT, MI, 48207-4635
RE: License#: CP820201496
WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - SOUTHCENTRAL
1801 E CANFIELD ST,
DETROIT, MI, 48207-4635
Dear Ms. Vega:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
12/8/2022. An exit conference occurred with the agency on 12/28/2022. Due to the
violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of
any licensing statutes9 rules and are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan was not
successful.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 248-860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
(AMENDED - Added Missing Safety Alert)

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child
in a foster home, then both of the following shall be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services
One of eight foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (a) and (b) as
required by the rule. Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
R 400.12418 Development of services plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Five of 18 updated service plans (USP) reviewed
Two of 18 updated service plans reviewed (related to two of eight foster child records)
were late by 11 and 13 days respectively. Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022,
Renewal 2021.
R400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
One of three initial service plans reviewed did not show documentation of(c) as required
by the rule. Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022.

R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
In one of three initial service plans reviewed the plan documented that the foster
parent/caregiver was not to use physical discipline and was to abide by agency’s policy,
but not what specific behavior management plan the foster parent/caregiver was to use
with the child. Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022.
R400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), shall include all of the following
information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes
made since the previous plan and which is to be used by
the foster parents.
In one of 17 updated service plans reviewed (related to one of eight foster child records)
the plan documented that the foster parent/caregiver was not to use physical discipline
and was to abide by agency’s policy, but not what specific behavior management plan
the foster parent/caregiver was to use with the child. Repeat Violation- Interim- March
2022.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated
child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will
be the primary tracking system and satisfy federal
reporting requirements.
Various open foster child records reviewed did not show consistent MISACWIS
uploads of all signed service plans, parent agency treatment plan agreements, FTM
DHS-1105, DHS-69s, medical passport documentation or other documents, at the
time of review. Proof of the documents were provided prior to exit.

ISEP 6.19 (5) (c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment
69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker's supervisor, the parent(s}, and the child(ren),
if of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
One of 21 service plans reviewed did not show documentation of the birth parent’s
signature. Repeat Violation- Interim March 2022.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team meeting
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include
extended family, friends, neighbors, community-based
service providers, community representatives, tribal
representatives, for Indian children, or other professionals
involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required
time frames as out lined in the following table.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance as required
by the policy:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s 2/2/2022-
5/2/2022 USP reporting period. The same record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the child’s AWOL and three placement changes thereafter.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
8/1/2022-8/30/2022 ISP reporting period.
• A third child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
3/23/2022-6/14/2022 or 6/15/2022-9/12/2022 USP reporting period.
Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022, Renewal 2021.

FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans
within 14 days of the end of the report period.
Two of 21 service plans reviewed (related to two of eight foster child records) were late
by two and seven days respectively. Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022, Renewal
2021.
FOM 722-08D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.
Six of 21 service plans reviewed (related to three of eight child records) did not show
compliance:
• One child’s 4/22/2022-5/20/2022 ISP treatment plan and 5/21/2022-8/12/2022
USP treatment plan did not contain the caregiver’s signature.
• A second child’s 2/22/2022-3/22/2022 ISP treatment plan, as well as, 3/23/2022-
6/14/2022 and 6/15/2022-9/12/2022 USP treatment was not signed by the
caregiver until 12/13/2022, 12/5/2022 and 12/5/2022 respectively.
• A third child’s 7/1/2022-9/27/2022 USP treatment was not signed by the caregiver.
Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022.
FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
Completion Requirements:
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
• Within three business days of foster care or
juvenile justice program case closure.
• Three days prior to a planned placement change,
or within three business days of an emergency
placement change.

Two of four closed foster child records reviewed showed the action summary was
completed late, per the rule:
• The action summary was completed on 12/5/2022 with respect to one child’s
9/21/22 case closure.
• The action summary related to the second child’s 8/22/2022 return home, and
subsequent 9/16/2022 case closure were both completed on 11/23/2022.
Repeat Violation- Interim- March 2022.
FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to
the child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the
youth is age 18 or older or has been legally emancipated,
at the time of closure:
• A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain
a copy in the case record).
• The child's social security card.
• Any available education records; see FOM 723,
Educational Services.
In two of four closed foster child records reviewed, the record did not show documentation
a copy of the child’s birth certificate and social security card were provided. One of these
records also did not show documentation that available education records were provided.
Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022.
FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
Initial Medical Passport:
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the child's
placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation the medical
passport was provided the caregiver at the child’s initial placement. Repeat- Interim,
March 2022.
FOM 802 Mental health and behavioral and developmental need
of children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a
mental health screening within 30 days of removal. The
screening instrument must be completed by a person who
knows the child best, before the child's Early Periodic,

Screening, Diagnostic, and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child
exam.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance as required by
the policy. Repeat Violation- Interim, March 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
FOM 722-D Treatment plans
• The agency was apprised that treatment plans shall be consistently dated and
any notation related to a birth parent’s or caregiver’s refusal to sign the
document shall also be dated.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was requested or required during this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The corrective action plan related to the agency’s Interim inspection where the
agency received the following rule and policy violations:
• R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
• R400.12405(5)(a) & (b)Change of placement.
• R400.12413(1)(c)(i) &(ii)Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12413(1)(f) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2)(b) Development of service plans.
• R400.12419(1)(c) & (h) Initial service plans.
• R400.12420(1)(g) Updated service plans.
• R400.12421(b) Visitation and parenting time.
• MISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight.
• MISEP 619 (5) Assessments and Service Plans, Content.
• FOM 722-06B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans, Overview, Types, and Timeframes-
Supervisor Approval.
• FOM 722-08 D Treatment plans; Agreement & Signature.
• FOM 722-08 E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary- Completion
Requirements.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge Documents.

• FOM 801-03 Medical Passport.
• FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of Children
under supervision of MDHHS.
In terms of the agency’s March 2022 Interim Inspection corrective action plan, the
agency made progress, but was not totally successful with all aspects of the plan.
This was notwithstanding its demonstrated enhanced monitoring tools. The agency
provided proof of various trainings, meetings, supervisory email reminders, outlook
calendar postings, new process for completion of initial relative safety screens and
3130As; wells as, the transfer of cases from child protective services to foster care,
DCWL (Department of Child Welfare Licensing) Audit reviews, and other oversight
tools/efforts implemented. The agency reduced noncompliance in some areas but
not all, as illustrated by the repeat violations cited in this Renewal inspection report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 12/5/2022 was received and reviewed. The
agency assessed its areas of noncompliance as indicated in the March 2022 Interim
Inspection report; and completed all other aspects as required by that document.
Interviews
The chief administrator, two section managers and two other supervisory staff
participated in the entrance conference. The entrance conference centered on a
review and discussion related to the last inspection’s corrective action plan, new
staff, and the agency’s current challenges, and status/program functioning. The
DCWL Analyst attended the entrance conference and presented her findings from
the unlicensed relative and foster home visits. The exit conference was attended by
the section manager, the district director in the chief administrator’s absence, and
three other supervisory staff. The exit conference focused on a summary of staff
interviews, and the results of the inspection/ indicated rule and policy violations.
Five foster workers and two foster care supervisors were interviewed during this
inspection.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The agency had two safety alerts this reporting period:
Safety Alert # 1:
Concern:
One foster child reported on 12/1/2022 that he was whooped with a belt by his aunt
the day before the DCWL Analyst’s visit. This child also reported he was hit by his
uncle that same day. The child also reported receiving whooping when he gets in
trouble and being whooped with an extension cord by his uncle. The other foster
child in the home reported the aunt hits him in the mouth when he talks back. It was
indicated that this information was not shared with the foster care worker because
the aunt is always present.
Resolution:
The DCWL Analyst made a centralize intake report related to the alleged
maltreatment. The agency conferenced this matter with the foster care staff on
12/2/2022 and verified relative home visits for 10/11/2022, 11/23/2022. The agency

reported that during both the October and November caregiver home visit each child
was seen by the foster care worker without the relative caregiver; and the children
did not disclose physical discipline being used by the caregivers. The children
reported discipline being timeout and removal of privileges.
The agency further reported that the foster care worker completed a home visit with
the assigned Maltreatment in Care (MIC)worker on 12/2/2022 and during that time
one child reported being hit on the hand, but reported the bruise being from an
incident at school, not his relative caregivers. The foster care staff safety planned
with the caregivers by advising that they are not to utilize any form of physical
discipline. The children were taken for medical examination on 12/2/2022. The
agency reported the MIC investigation related to the alleged maltreatment remains
underway.
Concern:
The carbon monoxide detector in the home was beeping. The relative caregiver was
informed of the need to replace the battery; and she stated she would replace the
battery. The agency was asked to verify that the battery was replaced.
Resolution:
The foster care worker provided the relative caregivers a carbon monoxide detector
on 12/2/2022.
Safety Alert # 2:
Concern:
The children are sleeping in the basement. There is not a window that is large enough to
be used for egress.
Resolution:
The agency contacted the relative caregiver to address the safety concern. The relative
caregiver agreed to move the children’s’ bunk bed upstairs into her daughter's room so all
of the children would be out of the basement. This was to occur the evening of 11/22/22
and the relative caregiver agreed to send the agency’s specialist and supervisor pictures
of the upstairs bedroom once the move was completed. The agency provided photos
showing the bunkbed had been moved from the basement into the stated room. The
agency also discussed with the relative caregiver the option of assisting them financially
with renovations to the basement to assure there is an egress window and appropriate
space designated in the basement for a bedroom to allow the three teen girls to have more
space until the family can move to a larger home.
Concern:
There is no smoke detector or carbon monoxide detector in the basement.
Resolution:
The agency provided a smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector for the basement.
The agency provided a photo showing the smoke/carbon monoxide detector installed in
the basement.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
12/29/2022
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
